instruction: Analyze the story and classify it into one of the following story arc types based on the protagonist's condition at each major event. Explain your reasoning step by step.
input:
Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) In 2008, hedge fund manager and recovering alcoholic Kevin Garner loses his job following the collapse of Bear Stearns.
2) Devastated and planning to fall off the wagon, Kevin goes to a bar, where he is interrupted right before the first drink by a woman named Molly, who approaches him on a dare from her friends.
3) The two hit it off, Kevin decides to continue his sobriety, asks Molly out on a formal date, and they ultimately get married.
4) Years later, Kevin and Molly are estranged following the disappearance of their son, Daniel.
5) Molly has become an embittered alcoholic and Kevin is unhappy in his job, as his younger boss hates people like him because his parents lost their home in the subprime mortgage crisis.
6) After learning he will be fired, Kevin leaves work and during a drive home ends up in a car accident, apparently pulled from the wreck by a mysterious stranger who identifies himself only as "The Benefactor".
7) The Benefactor tells Kevin that he has actually "shifted" him to another reality following the accident, and that they're now in a parallel universe.
8) The Benefactor and Kevin go to a café, and Kevin sees that all the staff and patrons inside are terrified of the Benefactor.
9) After a tense conversation at the table, Kevin realizes that the Benefactor is actually Satan.
10) The Benefactor offers Kevin anything he wants so long as he works as one of his "shifters", people who have sold their souls and use "shifting" for transferring other people to alternate universes, thus making the transferees swap places with their doppelgangers in those other universes - all versions of Kevin from other realities already work as his "shifters"; what's more, Kevin's wife has already been "shifted" twice, without anything being noticed.
11) Kevin is skeptical and asks the Benefactor to prove it, suggesting that Tina, a waitress in the café, be "shifted" for demonstration.
12) The Benefactor does just that, then informing Kevin that he's intentionally "shifted" Tina to a universe in which she's never existed, and that such "shifts" are cruel because of deranging effects on the "shifted" person's psyche.
13) Realizing that this action will drive Tina insane, Kevin begins to say under his breath a prayer to God for help.
14) Enraged, the Benefactor snarls that he'll never leave Kevin alone and that he's better than God and certainly better than Kevin, before vanishing abruptly and leaving Kevin trapped in that dystopian universe.
15) Horrified at what he's just done, Kevin apologizes to Tina's family and leaves.
16) Five years later, Kevin is still in the totalitarian reality, living under an assumed name because of "illicit prayer" at the café by "Kevin who refused".
17) In that universe, most of the planet was destroyed by constant war and anthropogenic activity with deleterious environmental impact.
18) At first the "shifters" operated in secret, moving between alternate universes and exiling anybody regarded as "problematic" by the regime, with the help of small wrist-worn shifting devices called "deviators"; with millions of people vanished without trace, order could be restored in remaining areas of human habitation.
19) After the Benefactor arrived and the surviving world leaders ceded control to him, he made the world over in his image.
20) Majority of people live in squalid, poverty-stricken cities ruled with an iron fist by the Benefactor's secret police.
21) Kevin attempts to write down from memory as many passages from the Bible and as closely to original text as he can remember and distributes the typed pages through his friend Gabriel, despite Scripture being illegal.
22) Kevin also shares the story of Job with his neighbor, Rajit, and his family.
23) Kevin's only solace is going to a movie theater owned by Russo, which plays a live feed from the viewer's direct doppelgangers in alternate realities.
24) In the theater, Kevin sees several versions of Molly, one of which is a single mother working as a nurse and still wearing a necklace that Kevin bought for her before their estrangement and which only the "original" Molly wore until she was replaced by the Benefactor with her doppelganger.
25) Kevin plans to obtain a deviator from one of the "shifters", but their identities are secret.
26) Kevin hears an announcement on TV that the Benefactor is returning to that reality for the first time in five years, and acquires an illegal firearm from Gabriel, intending to force the Benefactor to take him back to his previous life in the old reality.
27) However, the plan fails and the police open fire during a raid on Rajit's adjacent apartment, wounding Rajit and knocking Gabriel unconscious.
28) Kevin sees a deviator on Gabriel's wrist and realizes that Gabriel has been one of the Benefactor's secret "shifters" all along, shifting himself to another reality with Gabriel's deviator.
29) Kevin shifts through several universes, in one of them coming across Tina, who is unhinged and in a psychiatric ward.
30) The next shift with the deviator brings him back to his bullet-riddled apartment in the dystopian reality.
31) He runs to Russo's cinema and together they are able to identify the other universe from which the view of Molly with the necklace originates; after feeding the coordinates into the deviator, Kevin is shifted to that universe.
32) Molly in that universe is upset by conversation with Kevin, suggesting that they both should move on and reminding him that break-up of their marriage was initiated by him - but Kevin also feels that their relationship could be still revived.
33) Suddenly the Benefactor returns Kevin to the totalitarian universe, shifts Tina to Russo's cinema and tells Kevin that he should choose between restoring Tina to her family (never to see Molly again) and staying with Molly forever after accepting the Benefactor's offer to become his shifter.
34) Kevin decides to give Tina her life back, and immediately after that he's suddenly shifted to another reality.
35) In that reality, Molly is the nurse and single mother he saw previously and doesn't recognise him.
36) He strikes up a conversation similar to their first meeting, and the two get married once again.
37) Kevin states that although this is not his universe, it is his home.
38) He's seen playing with his newborn son and his adopted daughter, proving that he was given double what he lost.
39) In a post-credits scene, Kristoffer Polaha (who portrays Kevin in the film) thanks all viewers for watching the film and briefly mentions the inspirations for its screenplay and behind its production.

- Rags to Riches: Protagonist starts disadvantaged and ends better (e.g., 0→1→2→4→10)
- Riches to Rags: Protagonist starts high and ends lower (e.g., 10→9→8→6→0)
- Man in a Hole: Protagonist falls into trouble but recovers (e.g., 6→2→1→4→10)
- Icarus: Protagonist rises then falls dramatically (e.g., 2→4→9→5→1)
- Double Man in a Hole: Two cycles of fall and recovery (e.g., 6→2→7→4→10)
- Cinderella: Rise, setback, ultimate triumph (e.g., 1→7→4→1→10)
- Oedipus: Start high, fall, recover, final fall (e.g., 10→4→7→9→1)
output:
### TASK RESPONSE

### 1. Protagonist and Major Events Identification
The protagonist in the story is Kevin Garner. Here are 5 major events in the story:

- Event 1: Kevin loses his job (Sentence 1)
- Event 2: Kevin meets Molly, decides to continue his sobriety, and they get married (Sentences 2-3)
- Event 3: Kevin's life falls apart after his son's disappearance and he meets the Benefactor (Sentences 4-10)
- Event 4: Kevin is trapped in the totalitarian reality and tries to find a way back to his original life (Sentences 11-28)
- Event 5: Kevin makes a selfless choice, and as a result, he is shifted to a new reality where he reunites with Molly and starts a new life (Sentences 29-38)

### 2. Protagonist's State and Change at Each Event

- Event 1: Kevin's state is low, having lost his job and struggling with his sobriety. (State: 2)
- Event 2: Kevin's state improves significantly as he meets Molly, decides to continue his sobriety, and they get married. His life is on the upswing. (State: 8)
- Event 3: Kevin's state takes a drastic turn for the worse as his son disappears, his marriage falls apart, and he meets the Benefactor, who offers him a deal that could compromise his values. (State: 1)
- Event 4: Kevin's state remains low as he is trapped in the totalitarian reality, struggling to survive and find a way back to his original life. (State: 1)
- Event 5: Kevin's state improves dramatically as he makes a selfless choice, is shifted to a new reality, reunites with Molly, and starts a new life. His life is once again on the upswing. (State: 10)

### 3. Story Arc Type Classification
Based on the protagonist's condition throughout the story, the story arc type can be classified as Cinderella. The protagonist rises (Event 2), faces a setback (Event 3), and ultimately achieves a higher state (Event 5). The story follows a clear upward trajectory, with the protagonist overcoming significant challenges to achieve a better life.

### 4. Determined Story Arc Type
Cinderella

input:
Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) The film plot begins to unfold as Dylan Hendricks, who's navigating the arduous world of law, and his partner Naomi O'Sullivan, a gifted painter renowned for her works, find themselves wrestling with numerous personal and legal dilemmas, which are primarily due to their struggle with substance addiction.
2) Driven by a desire for solace and rehabilitation, they purchase a secluded 20-acre estate in the tranquil wilderness of Montana.
3) Their newly acquired property provides an escape from the bustling city life of New York, offering them a serene space for healing and transformation.
4) As they grow accustomed to their expansive property, they stumble upon an undisclosed rustic cabin, hidden within the lush, emerald-green pine woods.
5) In an attempt to unravel the mysterious origin of the cabin, they approach their real estate agent, Madeline Stone.
6) After prodding, Madeline hesitantly admits that Eddie Thornton, a former heroin-addict with no legal claims over the property, has been residing in the cabin.
7) Surprisingly, rather than being taken aback or infuriated, Dylan and Naomi permit Eddie to persist in his unusual home.
8) However, Eddie’s eccentric behaviour and peculiar routines begin to disrupt Dylan and Naomi's anticipated serene lifestyle.
9) Eddie's untypical lifestyle includes bizarre friends such as a boisterous, retired clown and a flame-swallowing stunt artist.
10) Their peaceful slumber is abruptly disturbed when Eddie starts playing African Djembe drums in the early fervour of dawn.
11) The comedic exploits hit an unforeseen peak when a friendly Golden Retriever, digging enthusiastically in their backyard, unearths bagfuls of Eddie's old illicit substances, instigating a full-scale police raid that disrupts their tranquil mountain life even further.
12) Due to his troubled past, Dylan regularly joins Narcotics Anonymous meetings.
13) Eddie, misunderstanding these gatherings, naively treats them as casual social meets.
14) Eddie's innocence leads him to thoughtlessly introduce marijuana to the group meeting, causing uproar.
15) Spurred by a mixture of curiosity, frustration and intrigue, Dylan and Naomi decide to delve into Eddie's dwelling.
16) To their astonishment, they discover an elaborately hidden system incorporated within the cabin, designed to conceal a valuable collection of baseball cards and pre-second World War stamps stolen over the years.
17) They start piecing together patterns of Eddie's turbulent past, which reveals how his peculiar hobby had helped him navigate through his strenuous journey towards recovery.
18) Instead of being repelled by Eddie's eccentricities, they find common ground in their past and hopes for sobriety, forging an unexpected connection through shared stories.
19) Eddie’s life experiences are initially bewildering, yet his street-smart sensibilities support Dylan in facing his own addiction history, facilitating a process of reconciliation.
20) Their lives take an unforeseen twist when Eddie is abruptly abducted by a local biker gang seeking to lay their hands on his hidden collectables.
21) Driven by a sense of camaraderie and brotherhood, Dylan and Naomi decide on an audacious plan to free Eddie, embarking on a wild adventure in their rugged old Jeep.
22) Despite numerous roadblocks and comedic diversions, their fierce determination clinches their victory, and they manage to free Eddie from the dreary confines of a dilapidated bar's basement.
23) This shared adventure brings them to the realization that Eddie has become more akin to a family member than a mere intriguing outcast.
24) Back at their estate, their triumph brings newfound fulfilment and solidarity within their uniquely formed family.
25) To make their connection official, they extend an invitation to Eddie to abandon the shack in the woods to become a permanent fixture at the main house.
26) The film concludes on a quirky twist, revolving around the discovery of another unexpected squatter - a reclusive potter found living tranquilly in a treehouse on the banks of their river.
27) Welcoming their reality with humor, Dylan, Naomi, and Eddie burst into shared hearty laughter, preparing for their next series of misadventures.

Story Arc Types:
- Rags to Riches: Protagonist starts disadvantaged and ends better (e.g., 0→1→2→4→10)
- Riches to Rags: Protagonist starts high and ends lower (e.g., 10→9→8→6→0)
- Man in a Hole: Protagonist falls into trouble but recovers (e.g., 6→2→1→4→10)
- Icarus: Protagonist rises then falls dramatically (e.g., 2→4→9→5→1)
- Double Man in a Hole: Two cycles of fall and recovery (e.g., 6→2→7→4→10)
- Cinderella: Rise, setback, ultimate triumph (e.g., 1→7→4→1→10)
- Oedipus: Start high, fall, recover, final fall (e.g., 10→4→7→9→1)
output:
**Task 1: Identify the protagonist and major events**

The protagonists in this story are Dylan Hendricks and Naomi O'Sullivan, but for simplicity, we will focus on Dylan as the primary protagonist. Here are 5 major events in the story:

1. Dylan and Naomi purchase a secluded 20-acre estate in Montana to escape their struggles with substance addiction ( Sentence 2).
2. They discover Eddie Thornton living in a hidden cabin on their property and permit him to stay (Sentences 6-7).
3. Eddie's eccentric behavior and the discovery of his hidden collectables disrupt Dylan and Naomi's peaceful life, but they also form a connection with Eddie through shared stories of addiction (Sentences 8-18).
4. Eddie is abducted by a local biker gang, and Dylan and Naomi embark on a wild adventure to rescue him (Sentences 20-22).
5. They successfully rescue Eddie, and he becomes a permanent fixture at their main house, forming a uniquely formed family (Sentences 23-25).

**Task 2: Describe the protagonist's state at each event**

1. At the first event, Dylan is struggling with substance addiction and seeking solace in a new environment. His state is low due to his addiction struggles.
2. At the second event, Dylan is still recovering from his addiction, but he shows compassion and understanding by permitting Eddie to stay on their property. His state is slightly improved due to his newfound sense of purpose and responsibility.
3. At the third event, Dylan's life is disrupted by Eddie's eccentric behavior, but he also forms a connection with Eddie through shared stories of addiction. His state is still uncertain, but he is beginning to find a sense of belonging and connection.
4. At the fourth event, Dylan's state is one of concern and determination as he embarks on a wild adventure to rescue Eddie from the biker gang.
5. At the fifth event, Dylan's state is one of triumph, solidarity, and fulfillment as he successfully rescues Eddie and forms a uniquely formed family.

**Task 3: Classify the story arc type**

Based on the protagonist's condition throughout the story, we can see that Dylan starts in a low state due to his addiction struggles, but as the story progresses, he forms connections, finds purpose, and ultimately achieves a higher state of fulfillment and solidarity. This pattern matches the "Man in a Hole" story arc type, where the protagonist falls into a dilemma (addiction) and finds a way out, ending better than at the beginning.

**Task 4: State the determined story arc type**

Man in a Hole

instruction: Analyze the story and classify it into one of the following story arc types based on the protagonist's condition at each major event. Explain your reasoning step by step.
input:
Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) One night in 1990, a teenaged girl drives on a highway, stalked by a motorist.
2) After stopping at an abandoned gas station, she catches the attention of a passing truck driver and escapes her pursuer.
3) Some time later in Bakersfield, Kern County Sheriff's Office Deputy Sheriff Joe "Deke" Deacon is sent to the Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department to collect evidence pertaining to a recent murder.
4) A former LASD detective, he accompanies recently appointed lead detective Jimmy Baxter to the scene of a new murder in L.A. Deacon notices similarities between the M.O.
5) of the killing and the M.O.
6) of an old serial murder case he was unable to solve.
7) That night, a woman named Ronda Rathbun is followed by a car while jogging and is reported missing the following morning.
8) Baxter learns from Captain Farris that Deacon had gotten divorced and suffered a heart attack due to his obsession with the unsolved case.
9) So, he is advised not to involve him any further but Deacon takes vacation leave from his station to assist in solving Baxter's case.
10) The next night, the police discover the body of another victim washed up beneath a bridge.
11) Baxter learns the M.O.
12) is consistent with the earlier murder and others: the victims were all sex workers who were stabbed to death.
13) Deacon begins investigating Albert Sparma, a suspect working at a repair store in proximity to the murders.
14) He tails him but is thwarted, so he takes him in for questioning.
15) While under interrogation, Sparma taunts the detectives and is released after provoking Deacon into an angry outburst.
16) The young woman pursued in the desert is interviewed but has seen Sparma in handcuffs at the police station which compromises her eligibility as an objective witness to identify him as a suspect.
17) The FBI will take charge of the investigation within the week, giving Deacon and Baxter less time to resolve it.
18) Farris informs Baxter that eight years prior, Sparma confessed to a murder which he couldn't possibly have committed and is thus an unlikely suspect.
19) Baxter and Deacon nonetheless continue investigating.
20) Sparma's fingerprint is similar to the killer's but not a definitive match.
21) Their next move is an illegal search at Sparma's apartment.
22) With Baxter standing guard outside, Deacon unsuccessfully searches the apartment for incriminating evidence, only finding newspaper clippings related to the cases.
23) Suddenly Sparma's police scanner goes off and Deacon hears an "officer down" alert for this very address.
24) As police converge on the building, Deacon narrowly escapes over the roof, with Sparma watching his ordeal and casually waving his hand at Baxter.
25) While surveilling Sparma, Baxter corners the suspect alone and demands to know Rathbun's location.
26) Sparma offers to drive him to where he supposedly hid Rathbun's body.
27) Baxter cautiously agrees while Deacon secretly follows.
28) Sparma takes Baxter to a remote area in the desert and has him dig several holes before telling him that he never killed anyone.
29) Skeptical, he continues digging.
30) Sparma begins to taunt him until Baxter snaps and strikes him in the face with the shovel, killing him.
31) As Deacon arrives, a flashback reveals that he accidentally shot the one survivor of his last murder case and that Farris and Dunigan, the coroner, helped cover it up.
32) Deacon instructs Baxter to bury Sparma in the desert, while he spends the night collecting everything in Sparma's apartment and disposing of his vehicle.
33) Then he returns to the desert the following morning to find that Baxter has not buried Sparma but is instead still searching for the victim, desperate to believe he is the killer.
34) Deacon (whose waking dreams are haunted by the earlier victims) advises Baxter to forget about the case or it will haunt him for life.
35) Later, at his home, Baxter receives an envelope sent by Deacon, containing a red barrette like the one Ronda Rathbun was wearing when she was abducted.
36) Back in Kern County, Deacon burns everything he collected in the apartment, along with a brand new pack of barrettes that is missing the red one.
37) Then, he walks away.

- Rags to Riches: Protagonist starts disadvantaged and ends better (e.g., 0→1→2→4→10)
- Riches to Rags: Protagonist starts high and ends lower (e.g., 10→9→8→6→0)
- Man in a Hole: Protagonist falls into trouble but recovers (e.g., 6→2→1→4→10)

output:
### Task 1: Identify the Protagonist and 5 Major Events

The protagonist of the story is Deputy Sheriff Joe "Deke" Deacon.

Here are 5 major events in the story:

1. Deacon is sent to the Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department to collect evidence pertaining to a recent murder (Sentence 3).
2. Deacon takes vacation leave from his station to assist in solving Baxter's case, despite being advised not to get involved (Sentence 9).
3. Deacon and Baxter's investigation leads to the identification of Albert Sparma as a suspect, but Sparma is released after provoking Deacon into an angry outburst (Sentences 13-15).
4. Deacon and Baxter continue investigating Sparma, leading to an illegal search of his apartment and a confrontation that ends with Sparma's death (Sentences 21-30).
5. Deacon helps Baxter cover up Sparma's death and advises him to forget about the case, before returning to Kern County to destroy evidence and reflect on his past mistakes (Sentences 32-37).

### Task 2: Describe the Protagonist's State at Each Event

1. At the first event, Deacon is in a relatively neutral state, carrying out his duties as a deputy sheriff. However, it is revealed that he has a troubled past and is haunted by an unsolved case (Sentence 8).
   State: 6 (neutral with a hint of past troubles)

2. At the second event, Deacon's state worsens as he becomes obsessed with solving the case, despite being advised not to get involved. This obsession is driven by his past failure and his desire for redemption.
   State: 4 (lower than before, as his obsession takes over)

3. At the third event, Deacon's state falls further as he is provoked by Sparma and loses his temper. This outburst reveals Deacon's emotional vulnerability and his deep-seated anger.
   State: 2 (lower than before, as he loses control)

4. At the fourth event, Deacon's state appears to improve as he and Baxter close in on Sparma. However, this is a temporary high, as the confrontation ends in disaster and Sparma's death.
   State: 7 (briefly higher, but ultimately a false peak)

5. At the fifth event, Deacon's state falls to a new low as he is forced to confront the consequences of his actions and the darkness of his own past. He is haunted by his mistakes and is left to ponder the morality of his actions.
   State: 1 (lowest point, as he faces the truth about himself)

### Task 3: Classify the Story Arc Type

Based on the protagonist's condition throughout the story, I classify the story arc type as Oedipus. This is because Deacon starts in a relatively high state, falls to a low point, briefly recovers, and then falls to an even lower point. This pattern matches the Oedipus story arc, which is characterized by a high-low-high-low trajectory.

Deacon's story arc is marked by a series of downward spirals, as he becomes increasingly obsessed with solving the case and is forced to confront the darkness of his own past. Despite brief moments of recovery, Deacon's overall trajectory is one of decline and despair.

### Task 4: State the Determined Story Arc Type

Oedipus

19) 's father Ivan Moss (Dub Taylor), who thinks the couple—and an ornate tattoo—have corrupted his son.

The protagonists of the story are Bonnie and Clyde. Since they are a duo and their story arc is intertwined, we can analyze their state together. Here are the 5 major events in the story:

1. Event 1: Bonnie and Clyde meet and decide to become partners in crime (sentences 1-2).
2. Event 2: They pull off some holdups and their crime spree shifts into high gear with the help of C.W. Moss (sentences 3-5).
3. Event 3: They turn to robbing banks and their exploits become more violent (sentences 7-10).
4. Event 4: The gang is pursued by law enforcement, and Buck is mortally wounded in a raid (sentences 11-14).
5. Event 5: Bonnie and Clyde are ambushed and killed by the police (sentences 20-22).

### TASK 2: Describe the Protagonist's State at Each Event

### TASK 3: Classify the Story Arc Type

Based on the protagonist's condition throughout the story, we can classify the story arc type as Icarus. The protagonist's state starts low, rises to a peak, and then falls to a low point. This matches the example of the Icarus story arc: 2 4 9 5 1.

In this story, Bonnie and Clyde start with a low state, bored and struggling to make a living. They rise to a peak as they gain success and notoriety with their crimes. However, their downfall begins when they face setbacks and are pursued by law enforcement, ultimately leading to their demise.

instruction: Analyze the story and classify it into one of the following story arc types based on the protagonist's condition at each major event. Explain your reasoning step by step.
input:
Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) In Havana, Cuba, Andrés Hernández and his kinkajou Vivo play music together in the plaza.
2) One day after their show, Andrés receives a letter from his old friend, Marta Sandoval, informing him that she is retiring from her music career.
3) The letter offers a chance to reconnect in Miami, at the Mambo Cabana and for Andrés to finally confess his love for Marta through a song he wrote just for her.
4) Vivo, happy with their life in Cuba, is reluctant to help Andrés.
5) The next morning, Andrés dies in his sleep and that night, a funeral service is held in the plaza, with Andrés' niece-in-law Rosa and her daughter Gabi attending before they head back to their home in Key West, Florida.
6) Ashamed of his earlier reluctance, Vivo vows himself to get Marta to hear Andrés' song.
7) He stows away to Key West with Gabi and Rosa in their luggage.
8) Gabi finds Vivo and agrees to help him deliver Andrés' song to Marta.
9) Under the guise of attending a cookie sale in town, Gabi and Vivo purchase bus tickets to get to Marta's show, but they are stopped by the Sand Dollars, a girl scout troop who wants Vivo vaccinated.
10) Gabi and Vivo escape from them, but miss the bus.
11) They end up in the Everglades and are separated by a heavy rain storm, losing the song.
12) While searching for Gabi, Vivo comes across a roseate spoonbill named Dancarino, who is unsuccessful in finding love with one of his own.
13) With Vivo's help, he is able to win the heart of Valentina.
14) The two later rescue Vivo from a Burmese python named Lutador.
15) Meanwhile, Gabi discovers that she was followed by the Sand Dollars on a boat and that they have Andrés' song, keeping it from her until she leads them to Vivo.
16) When the girls are attacked by Lutador, Vivo saves them, but the song is destroyed in the process.
17) Devastated, Vivo considers returning to Cuba until he realizes he and Gabi can recreate the song, as he knows the melody and Gabi knows the lyrics.
18) Together, they make it to Miami and search for Marta, who has learned of Andrés' death and refuses to go on stage.
19) Gabi and Vivo sneak inside the Mambo Cabana, but Gabi is unable to enter and tells Vivo to go on without her.
20) She is soon caught by security and her furious mother.
21) Vivo finds a mourning Marta, who recognizes him from Andrés' obituary photo, and delivers the song.
22) Touched by the song, Marta is revitalized and decides to go on stage.
23) Vivo then locates Gabi and Rosa, who are arguing while driving back home.
24) Gabi confesses she decided to help Vivo because she misses her deceased father Carlos.
25) Deeply moved, Rosa reassures her daughter, and drives Gabi and Vivo back to the concert just in time to hear Marta play Andrés' song.
26) Vivo decides to stay in Florida with Gabi and Rosa.
27) Gabi and Vivo put on their own show in the city with Marta, entertaining the crowd.

Story Arc Types:
- Rags to Riches: Protagonist starts disadvantaged and ends better (e.g., 0→1→2→4→10)
- Riches to Rags: Protagonist starts high and ends lower (e.g., 10→9→8→6→0)
- Man in a Hole: Protagonist falls into trouble but recovers (e.g., 6→2→1→4→10)
- Icarus: Protagonist rises then falls dramatically (e.g., 2→4→9→5→1)
- Double Man in a Hole: Two cycles of fall and recovery (e.g., 6→2→7→4→10)
- Cinderella: Rise, setback, ultimate triumph (e.g., 1→7→4→1→10)
- Oedipus: Start high, fall, recover, final fall (e.g., 10→4→7→9→1)
output:
### TASK 1: Identify the Protagonist and 5 Major Events

The protagonist of the story is Vivo, the kinkajou. Here are 5 major events in the story:

1. Andrés' death and Vivo's vow to get Marta to hear Andrés' song (Sentences 5-6)
2. Vivo's escape from the Sand Dollars and his separation from Gabi in the Everglades (Sentences 10-11)
3. Vivo's rescue by Dancarino and his help in winning Valentina's heart (Sentences 12-14)
4. Vivo's rescue of Gabi from Lutador and the destruction of Andrés' song (Sentences 15-16)
5. Vivo's delivery of the recreated song to Marta and his decision to stay with Gabi and Rosa (Sentences 21-26)

### TASK 2: Describe the Protagonist's State at Each Event

Here's the protagonist's state at each event and how it changed relative to the previous events:

1. Andrés' death and Vivo's vow: At this point, Vivo is filled with regret and shame for not supporting Andrés earlier. His state is low. (Initial state: 2)
2. Vivo's escape and separation from Gabi: Vivo's situation worsens as he faces obstacles and challenges in fulfilling his vow. His state falls further. (State: 1)
3. Vivo's rescue by Dancarino: Vivo's state improves slightly as he finds help and support from Dancarino and Valentina. (State: 3)
4. Vivo's rescue of Gabi and destruction of the song: Vivo's state falls again as he faces another setback and the song is destroyed. (State: 2)
5. Vivo's delivery of the recreated song: Vivo's state improves significantly as he successfully delivers the song to Marta and finds a new sense of purpose and belonging with Gabi and Rosa. (State: 8)

### TASK 3: Classify the Story Arc Type

Based on the protagonist's condition throughout the story, I classify the story arc type as "Man in a Hole." The protagonist, Vivo, starts in a relatively low state, falls into a deeper hole (literally and figuratively), and then finds a way out, ultimately ending in a better state than at the beginning. The story follows the pattern of a "Man in a Hole" arc, where the protagonist faces a series of challenges and setbacks but ultimately emerges stronger and more triumphant.

### TASK 4: State the Determined Story Arc Type

Man in a Hole

instruction: Analyze the story and classify it into one of the following story arc types based on the protagonist's condition at each major event. Explain your reasoning step by step.
input:
Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) Reclusive academic Augustine Lofthouse has devoted his life to finding habitable planets so humanity can expand.
2) He meets Jean Sullivan after giving a presentation at a gala and they form a romantic relationship.
3) After a pregnancy scare, she leaves him due to his work obsession and inability to bond with others.
4) Several years later, when Lofthouse encounters Jean again, she tells him about their daughter, whom he chooses not to meet.
5) Thirty years later, in 2049, an event has obliterated most of Earth's population and left the surface contaminated with ionizing radiation.
6) Lofthouse is the only person inhabiting a large Arctic base.
7) A flashback shows him refusing to join the evacuation, knowing he does not have long to live due to an unidentified serious illness requiring hemodialysis and medical equipment at the base.
8) Lofthouse searches the base's computer systems for active crewed space missions to warn about the situation on Earth, and finds only one: the interplanetary craft Aether, returning from an exploration of Jupiter's habitable moon K-23, which Lofthouse discovered.
9) In the meantime, the crew of Aether are oblivious to events on Earth and believe they have lost contact due to faulty communications systems.
10) Lofthouse finds his antenna is too weak to contact them, even after calculating them to be in range.
11) Along with his deteriorating physical health, Lofthouse is experiencing mental blackouts.
12) After a kitchen fire, he finds a young mute girl hiding in the kitchen.
13) He tries to contact the evacuees to get someone to get her, to no avail.
14) The girl draws an iris and Lofthouse deduces that this is her name.
15) Lofthouse grows fond of Iris and they travel together on a snowmobile to another base which has a larger, more powerful antenna.
16) En route, in an accident, he loses his medical equipment.
17) Arriving at the base, he manages to make contact with Aether, but an asteroid field damages the ship's radar and communication systems.
18) To repair the damage, mission specialist Sully, currently pregnant, and her partner, Commander Adewole, conduct a spacewalk with flight engineer Maya.
19) They repair the communications and radar, but are caught in a second asteroid field that fatally injures Maya.
20) Sully contacts Lofthouse.
21) He tells her not to return to Earth because of the disaster, but go back to K-23 and start a new life there.
22) Aether's pilot, Tom Mitchell, refuses, but upon discovering his wife's final words and seeing the state of Earth's atmosphere, he understands that it is in the crew's best interests to go back to Jupiter's moon.
23) Still, he chooses to use one of the two re-entry vehicles to return to Earth.
24) Sanchez, who saw Maya as a second daughter, decides to accompany him and bury her body on Earth.
25) In her final communication with Lofthouse, Sully tells him that he was one of the reasons she joined NASA.
26) She thanks him, telling him her mother Jean had given her a moon rock from him, and that her full name is Iris Sullivan.
27) Lofthouse says he already knew her name, making it clear that the young girl he had been seeing was not real.
28) When asked how he ended up at the base from which he contacted Aether, he says he thought he might be able to "help someone" (implying he followed Aether's mission not only because he discovered that moon, but also because it was his daughter Sully's mission).
29) Lofthouse tells Sully he is proud to have finally met her, and she describes K-23 to him.
30) Her description transports him there in his imagination and he falls out of radio contact.
31) Sully and Adewole are left with nothing but to return to K-23 using a course provided by Lofthouse.

- Cinderella: Rise, setback, ultimate triumph (e.g., 1→7→4→1→10)
- Oedipus: Start high, fall, recover, final fall (e.g., 10→4→7→9→1)
output:
### TASK 1: Identify the Protagonist and 5 Major Events

The protagonist of the story is Augustine Lofthouse. Here are 5 major events in the story:

1. Lofthouse meets Jean Sullivan and they form a romantic relationship (Event 2).
2. Jean leaves Lofthouse due to his work obsession, and he chooses not to meet their daughter (Events 3-4).
3. Lofthouse discovers that most of Earth's population has been obliterated and he is left alone at the Arctic base (Event 5-7).
4. Lofthouse meets the young mute girl, Iris, and grows fond of her, which motivates him to contact the Aether crew (Events 12-15).
5. Lofthouse successfully contacts the Aether crew and learns that Iris Sullivan is his daughter, and he finally feels a sense of connection and pride (Events 25-30).

### TASK 2: Describe the Protagonist's State at Each Event

Here's a description of Lofthouse's state at each event and how it changed relative to the previous events:

1. Event 2: Lofthouse meets Jean Sullivan and they form a romantic relationship. Lofthouse's state is high, as he has found someone who cares for him. (State: 8/10)
2. Event 3-4: Jean leaves Lofthouse, and he chooses not to meet their daughter. Lofthouse's state falls to a low point, as he has lost the person he cares about and is left with his own obsession. (State: 2/10)
3. Event 5-7: Lofthouse discovers that most of Earth's population has been obliterated, and he is left alone at the Arctic base. Lofthouse's state falls even further, as he is now isolated and struggling to survive. (State: 1/10)
4. Event 12-15: Lofthouse meets the young mute girl, Iris, and grows fond of her. Lofthouse's state improves slightly, as he has found someone to care for and a new sense of purpose. (State: 4/10)
5. Event 25-30: Lofthouse successfully contacts the Aether crew and learns that Iris Sullivan is his daughter. Lofthouse's state rises to a high point, as he finally feels a sense of connection and pride. (State: 9/10)

### TASK 3: Classify the Story Arc Type

Based on Lofthouse's state throughout the story, the story arc type can be classified as a Double Man in a Hole. The story follows two cycles of dilemma and recovery:

* The first cycle: Lofthouse falls from a high state (Event 2) to a low state (Event 3-4) and then recovers slightly (Event 12-15).
* The second cycle: Lofthouse falls again to a low state (Event 5-7) and then recovers to a high state (Event 25-30).

The story arc type is a Double Man in a Hole because Lofthouse faces two significant downturns (losing Jean and facing the apocalypse) but ultimately recovers and finds a sense of connection and pride.

### TASK 4: State the Determined Story Arc Type

Double Man in a Hole

instruction: Analyze the story and classify it into one of the following story arc types based on the protagonist's condition at each major event. Explain your reasoning step by step.
input:
Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) Noa, a woman from Portland, is increasingly disillusioned with online dating and the rude men she interacts with.
2) One day at the supermarket, a man named Steve flirts with her and they exchange numbers.
3) On their first date, the two quickly hit it off and have sex.
4) After several dates, Steve invites Noa for a weekend break away alone with him.
5) Against the advice of her best friend Mollie, Noa agrees to the trip.
6) Planning to travel early the following day, Noa spends the evening at Steve's luxury home.
7) Steve drugs Noa's cocktail and she falls unconscious.
8) Noa wakes up in captivity, chained to the ground.
9) Steve explains that he is a butcher of human meat, which he both consumes himself and sells to wealthy clients, revealing himself as a sadistic cannibal.
10) His clients prefer the meat of young women, so he regularly lures and abducts women on dates.
11) He says that he will keep Noa alive as long as possible in order to keep her meat fresh as he intends to surgically remove different pieces of her body over time.
12) Steve allows Noa to take a shower, but she tries to escape.
13) Steve captures her and harvests her buttocks as punishment.
14) Noa speaks to a woman named Penny who is being held captive in an adjacent room.
15) Penny shares with Noa that a woman that can be heard singing incoherently is another victim named Melissa who has gone insane.
16) Meanwhile, Mollie becomes concerned about Noa's disappearance and begins investigating with her friend Paul, a bartender who served Noa and Steve drinks on their first date.
17) After searching online, Mollie discovers Steve is actually named Brendan, and is married to a woman named Ann with whom he has children.
18) Mollie visits Ann and informs her of Brendan’s apparent affair.
19) Brendan arrives, but denies any knowledge of Noa when questioned by Mollie.
20) As she leaves, Mollie calls Noa's phone, which begins ringing in Brendan's pocket.
21) Ann, realizing he's been caught, knocks Mollie unconscious.
22) In a shower scene with Ann, it is revealed that she has a prosthetic leg, implying that she might have been one of Brendan's past victims.
23) Noa gains Brendan's trust by flirting and pretending to be interested in what human meat tastes like.
24) Brendan invites her to dinner and persuades her to taste a lavish meal containing human meat, which Noa eats, pretends to enjoy and later vomits in her cell.
25) Meanwhile, Brendan takes Mollie away for harvesting.
26) Brendan invites Noa to another dinner, providing her with a pink dress as a gift.
27) Before dinner, Brendan shows Noa a hidden compartment filled with items belonging to his victims, indicating he has abducted and murdered dozens of women before her.
28) While observing Brendan's trophies, Noa recognizes Mollie's phone amongst those of the kidnapped victims.
29) At dinner, he feeds Noa breast meat, which Brendan connotes as possibly tasting "familiar."
30) Following dinner, Noa persuades Brendan to have sex with her and let her perform fellatio on him; she instead, bites off his penis.
31) With Brendan injured, but in pursuit, Noa helps Mollie and Penny escape from their rooms.
32) The three encounter Brendan in the kitchen and fight him, then escape into the woods with Brendan pursuing them with a gun.
33) In the meantime, before she was abducted, Mollie had shared her location via phone with Paul.
34) When he does not hear back from Mollie, Paul follows the location and arrives at Brendan's house.
35) However, hearing gunshots fired by Brendan, Paul turns away fearing for his life.
36) In the woods, Noa, Mollie, and Penny manage to attack him again, with Noa taking the gun and shooting Brendan dead.
37) Ann arrives at the house and finds Brendan's body.
38) She encounters Noa in the woods and tries to strangle her, but Noa stabs Ann in the neck with car keys.
39) As Ann recovers and attempts to strangle Noa again, Mollie angrily bludgeons Ann to death with a shovel.
40) As she and Mollie relax at last, Noa receives a text from a man she went out with at the beginning of the film.
41) A mid-credits scene depicts five of Brendan's clients in a white room, seated at a table with bleeding human meat at the center.

Story Arc Types:
- Rags to Riches: Protagonist starts disadvantaged and ends better (e.g., 0→1→2→4→10)
- Riches to Rags: Protagonist starts high and ends lower (e.g., 10→9→8→6→0)
- Man in a Hole: Protagonist falls into trouble but recovers (e.g., 6→2→1→4→10)
- Icarus: Protagonist rises then falls dramatically (e.g., 2→4→9→5→1)
- Double Man in a Hole: Two cycles of fall and recovery (e.g., 6→2→7→4→10)
- Cinderella: Rise, setback, ultimate triumph (e.g., 1→7→4→1→10)
- Oedipus: Start high, fall, recover, final fall (e.g., 10→4→7→9→1)

The protagonist of the story is Noa, a woman from Portland.

Five major events in the story are:

1. Noa meets Steve (Brendan) and they go on a date (sentence 2-3).
2. Noa is drugged and wakes up in captivity, chained to the ground (sentence 7-8).
3. Noa gains Brendan's trust by flirting and pretending to be interested in human meat (sentence 23).
4. Noa bites off Brendan's penis and helps Mollie and Penny escape (sentence 30-31).
5. Noa kills Brendan and escapes with Mollie and Penny (sentence 36).

### TASK 2: Describe the protagonist's state and changes at each event

1. Initially, Noa is disillusioned with online dating, but after meeting Steve, she is hopeful and excited about the possibility of a new relationship. Her state is improving.
2. After being drugged and waking up in captivity, Noa's state drastically worsens. She is now in a life-threatening situation and is being held against her will.
3. When Noa gains Brendan's trust, her state slightly improves. She is still in captivity, but she has gained some control over her situation and is able to manipulate Brendan.
4. After biting off Brendan's penis and helping Mollie and Penny escape, Noa's state significantly improves. She is now taking action to free herself and others, and is fighting back against her captor.
5. Finally, when Noa kills Brendan and escapes with Mollie and Penny, her state is at its best. She has overcome her ordeal and is finally free.

### TASK 3: Classify the story arc type

Based on the protagonist's condition throughout the story, I would classify the story arc type as "Man in a Hole." This is because Noa starts in a relatively neutral state, falls into a dire situation (being held captive), and then finds a way to escape and ultimately ends up in a better state than at the beginning. Her condition worsens and then improves, following the typical "Man in a Hole" pattern.

instruction: Analyze the story and classify it into one of the following story arc types based on the protagonist's condition at each major event. Explain your reasoning step by step.
input:
Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) Jackson Briggs, a former U.S. Army Ranger suffering from PTSD, tries to apply for a rotation position in Pakistan, but is deemed unfit for service due to a brain injury.
2) He is notified that his friend and former partner, Riley Rodriguez, was killed in a car accident the night before.
3) The morning after attending a memorial service at a local bar, Briggs is called in to Fort Lewis on a special assignment to escort Riley's military dog, Lulu, a female Belgian Malinois with a history of aggressive behavior, to attend his funeral in Nogales, Arizona, after which he is to bring her to White Sands, where she will be euthanized.
4) Initially hesitant, Briggs agrees when his former company commander, Captain Jones, promises to recommend him for the position.
5) On the road, when Briggs stops at a shooting range, Lulu breaks out of her cage and destroys the inside of his 1984 Ford Bronco.
6) Frustrated, Briggs hides sedatives in a hot dog, causing Lulu to fall asleep after she eats it.
7) In Portland, Oregon, Briggs tries to hit on women in a bar, but most are repelled by his brash personality.
8) Outside, he meets two friends, Bella and Zoe, who invite him to their house for a threesome.
9) While Briggs is inside, Lulu panics, alerting a neighbor.
10) Believing her to be the victim of abuse, the neighbor frees her from the car, but is promptly attacked.
11) Briggs runs outsides and pulls them apart, but Bella and Zoe are disturbed by the display and lock Briggs outside.
12) The next morning, while on the Pacific Coast Highway, Lulu climbs out of the back of the car, forcing Briggs to pull over and chase her through a nearby forest.
13) They stumble across a marijuana farm in the woods, where Briggs is tranquilized by the farm's owner, Gus.
14) He wakes up tied to a chair in the shed, but he is able to escape.
15) He reunites with Lulu, who has injured her paw, and is being treated by Gus's wife, Tamara.
16) Briggs and Gus reconcile by looking through Lulu's "I Love Me" book, which contains photos from her service during the War in Afghanistan.
17) After Lulu is treated, Tamara gives Briggs a psychic reading before Briggs and Lulu continue on the road.
18) In San Francisco, Briggs cons a free hotel room by pretending to be a blind veteran, with Lulu as his seeing-eye dog.
19) Briggs takes her to his room and gives her a bath.
20) He tries to leave the room, but Lulu barks until Briggs relents and brings her with him.
21) In the lobby, Lulu attacks a Middle Eastern man, Dr. Al-Farid, and Briggs is arrested for a hate crime.
22) At the station, Briggs is put in a lineup, where he apologizes to Al-Farid, who agrees not to press charges on the condition that Briggs seek professional help for his behavior.
23) While retrieving Lulu, the medic reveals that she has anxiety.
24) In Los Angeles, Briggs tries to visit his estranged 3-year-old daughter, Sam, but his wife, Niki, does not allow him to.
25) Briggs visits Noah, a former Army Ranger who adopted and rehabilitated Lulu's brother, Nuke.
26) Noah teaches Briggs to bond with Lulu in terms she understands, allowing him to form a deeper connection with her.
27) After leaving Noah's, the Bronco breaks down during a thunderstorm, forcing Briggs and Lulu to shelter in an abandoned barn.
28) The next morning, Briggs and Lulu hitchhike to Nogales in time for the funeral, where Briggs stays with her to keep her calm during the traditional rifle salute.
29) Afterwards, while Briggs gets his truck repaired, he calls Jones and tells him that Lulu's condition has improved, but Jones is unconcerned.
30) Briggs drives into the desert and encourages Lulu to run away.
31) When she does not, they stay in a motel overnight.
32) Briggs suffers from a panic attack before going into a seizure, but is calmed by Lulu.
33) In the morning, Briggs drops Lulu off at White Sands, but changes his mind when he sees her panicking.
34) He drives back to the gate and takes Lulu back, driving away with her.
35) Months later, Briggs writes a letter addressed to her, revealing that he has adopted her.
36) He thanks her for saving his life and making him a better man as Niki takes him to meet Sam.

Story Arc Types:
- Rags to Riches: Protagonist starts disadvantaged and ends better (e.g., 0→1→2→4→10)
- Riches to Rags: Protagonist starts high and ends lower (e.g., 10→9→8→6→0)
- Man in a Hole: Protagonist falls into trouble but recovers (e.g., 6→2→1→4→10)
- Icarus: Protagonist rises then falls dramatically (e.g., 2→4→9→5→1)
- Double Man in a Hole: Two cycles of fall and recovery (e.g., 6→2→7→4→10)
- Cinderella: Rise, setback, ultimate triumph (e.g., 1→7→4→1→10)
- Oedipus: Start high, fall, recover, final fall (e.g., 10→4→7→9→1)
output:
### TASK 1: Identify the protagonist and major events

The protagonist in this story is Jackson Briggs, a former U.S. Army Ranger.

Here are 5 major events in the story:

1. Event 1: Briggs is deemed unfit for service due to a brain injury and is tasked with escorting Riley's military dog, Lulu, to attend his funeral in Nogales, Arizona (Sentence 3).
2. Event 2: Briggs's attempt to sedate Lulu fails, leading to a series of chaotic events, including Lulu's attack on a neighbor and Briggs being locked out of a house by two women (Sentences 6-11).
3. Event 3: Briggs has a turning point when he meets Gus and his wife, Tamara, who help him understand Lulu's behavior and form a deeper connection with her (Sentences 13-17).
4. Event 4: Briggs is arrested for a hate crime after Lulu attacks a Middle Eastern man, Dr. Al-Farid, but is released after apologizing and agreeing to seek professional help (Sentences 21-22).
5. Event 5: Briggs decides to adopt Lulu instead of taking her to be euthanized, and his life starts to improve as he forms a stronger bond with Lulu and eventually reunites with his daughter (Sentences 34-36).

### TASK 2: Describe the protagonist's state and changes at each event

1. Event 1: Briggs is in a low state, having been deemed unfit for service and struggling with PTSD. He is reluctant to take on the task of escorting Lulu, but sees it as an opportunity to prove himself.
	* State: Low (0)
2. Event 2: Briggs's state worsens as he struggles to control Lulu and faces a series of chaotic events. He is frustrated, angry, and feeling hopeless.
	* State: Lower (0 -> -2)
3. Event 3: Briggs has a turning point when he meets Gus and Tamara, who help him understand Lulu's behavior and form a deeper connection with her. He begins to see Lulu as a living being rather than just a task to be completed.
	* State: Improved (-2 -> 2)
4. Event 4: Briggs's state takes a hit when he is arrested for a hate crime, but he is able to apologize and agree to seek professional help. He is beginning to recognize his own flaws and take responsibility for his actions.
	* State: Setback (2 -> 0)
5. Event 5: Briggs decides to adopt Lulu and his life starts to improve as he forms a stronger bond with Lulu and eventually reunites with his daughter. He is grateful for Lulu's presence in his life and is starting to heal from his past traumas.
	* State: Improved (0 -> 8)

### TASK 3: Classify the story arc type and explain reasoning

Based on the protagonist's condition throughout the story, I would classify the story arc type as "Man in a Hole". The protagonist starts in a low state, falls even lower, but then has a turning point and begins to improve. He faces setbacks along the way, but ultimately ends up in a much better state than where he started.

The "Man in a Hole" story arc is characterized by a protagonist who faces a dilemma and finds a way out, ending better than at the beginning. In this story, Briggs faces the dilemma of being deemed unfit for service and struggling with PTSD, but he finds a way out by forming a deeper connection with Lulu and taking responsibility for his actions. He ends up in a much better state, having adopted Lulu and started to heal from his past traumas.

### TASK 4: State the determined story arc type

Man in a Hole

instruction: Analyze the story and classify it into one of the following story arc types based on the protagonist's condition at each major event. Explain your reasoning step by step.
input:
Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) In 1963, Joanne and Anthony Waxen live in a home built by Frederick Banner, with whom the two have had concerning interactions.
2) Joanne, a stay-at-home housewife is given underwear as a gift by her husband.
3) After Joanne leaves to change, Frederick enters the house.
4) Joanne finds Frederick peeking on her while Anthony has been hanged from the ceiling with a belt.
5) In 2022, Alice is a doctor who is harassed by her superior and is traumatized from her time working during the COVID-19 pandemic.
6) She and her architect husband Tom go on a weekend getaway to San Diego and rent a mid-century modern home, the same that was built by Frederick, from a mysterious man named Eldridge.
7) While there, strange events occur including a bird crashing into the window, doors opening by themselves, and a shadowy figure watching the couple while they have sex.
8) As night falls, a delivery driver tells Tom about Eldridge, stating he freaks him out.
9) After driving away, his tire pops and a man stabs him in the chest.
10) Following dinner, Alice goes to interview at a hospital for a new job.
11) The delivery driver is sent to Alice's hospital but she is unable to save him.
12) After finding the receipt for the order in his pocket, officer Raquel and her partner interrogate her, inquiring if Tom had anything to do with the murder.
13) Meanwhile, Tom investigates the house and Frederick Banner.
14) Tom searches Frederick on Wikipedia but finds a lot missing, so he calls his co-worker Hannah who he is sleeping with to find a book on him in their office.
15) The book reveals that Frederick lost his first wife Alice and later remarried Joanne Waxen, and that he was also interested in polygamy and the occult with a painter named Emil Larson.
16) Hannah hangs up but is soon-after strangled by a security guard.
17) At the house, Tom is haunted by a woman who, after nearly drowning Tom in the pool, leads him to a book of the occult and later to a grave in the backyard with the bones of Graham Verdin.
18) When Tom touches the bones he sees visions which reveal that the woman is Marie Verdin and the wife of Graham, a woman who Frederick was manipulating at the same time as Joanne whom he later kills and takes her son as his own, now named Eldridge Banner.
19) She reveals to Tom that Frederick killed the husbands of the couples who moved into his neighborhood and that he still haunted the house where he died.
20) Eldridge returns to the home and Tom calls 911 before falling into a ditch outside.
21) The two officers arrive at the house and question Eldridge, but do not go further as he is a top fundraiser for the police.
22) Tom is then possessed by Alice and talks to her son through him before he drowns Tom and buries him in the yard.
23) Tom however still exists as a ghost and spends time with Marie.
24) The two discover a recording of Frederick and Emil discussing a prophesied blood "wolf" moon in which a woman can be impregnated with a spirit.
25) The police discover the delivery driver was killed by an architect's compass, narrowing the suspect down to Eldridge or Tom.
26) Alice returns to the house after work and finds Tom missing.
27) Eldridge confronts Alice and sedates her, preparing for the ritual.
28) Tom then possesses Eldridge and digs up his own body before officer Raquel arrives and arrests him.
29) Tom, speaking through Eldridge, admits to everything and asks to be arrested.
30) The chief of police arrives and kills Raquel, revealing he is one of Eldridge's brother possessed by Frederick.
31) The ritual begins with sons of Frederick surrounding Alice.
32) Alice, and Tom possessing Alice, kill the sons together and say their goodbyes.
33) After Alice is transported to the hospital, Tom sees every house in the neighborhood has ghosts of Frederick's victims inside.

Story Arc Types:
- Rags to Riches: Protagonist starts disadvantaged and ends better (e.g., 0→1→2→4→10)
- Riches to Rags: Protagonist starts high and ends lower (e.g., 10→9→8→6→0)
- Man in a Hole: Protagonist falls into trouble but recovers (e.g., 6→2→1→4→10)
- Icarus: Protagonist rises then falls dramatically (e.g., 2→4→9→5→1)
- Double Man in a Hole: Two cycles of fall and recovery (e.g., 6→2→7→4→10)
- Cinderella: Rise, setback, ultimate triumph (e.g., 1→7→4→1→10)
- Oedipus: Start high, fall, recover, final fall (e.g., 10→4→7→9→1)
output:
### 1. Identify the Protagonist and 5 Major Events

The protagonist in this story is Alice, as the story revolves around her experiences and ultimate confrontation with the antagonist.

Here are 5 major events in the story:

1. Alice and Tom rent the mid-century modern home in San Diego (Event 6).
2. Alice fails to save the delivery driver and is interrogated by the police (Event 11-12).
3. Tom discovers the dark history of Frederick Banner and the house (Event 15-19).
4. Alice is sedated and prepared for the ritual by Eldridge (Event 27).
5. Alice, possessed by Tom, kills the sons of Frederick and escapes (Event 32).

### 2. Describe the Protagonist's State and Changes

1. **Event 6:** Alice is initially in a relatively stable state, trying to escape her traumatic past and start anew with her husband Tom. Her state is neutral, around 5.
2. **Event 11-12:** Alice's state worsens as she is unable to save the delivery driver and is interrogated by the police, making her a suspect. Her state drops to 3.
3. **Event 15-19:** Although this event primarily involves Tom, it sets the stage for Alice's future challenges. Alice's state remains at 3, as she is still unaware of the danger that awaits her.
4. **Event 27:** Alice's state plummets as she is sedated and prepared for the ritual, rendering her helpless. Her state drops to 1.
5. **Event 32:** Alice, possessed by Tom, manages to kill the sons of Frederick and escape. Although she is still traumatized, her state improves slightly to 2, as she has survived the ordeal.

### 3. Classify the Story Arc Type

Based on the protagonist's condition throughout the story, the story arc type can be classified as **Riches to Rags**. Alice starts in a relatively stable state, but her condition worsens as the story progresses, ultimately ending in a lower state.

The story arc follows a downward trajectory, with Alice's state deteriorating from 5 to 1, and only slightly improving to 2 at the end. This pattern matches the **Riches to Rags** story arc type, where the protagonist starts in a high-status position but ends in a significantly lower state.

### 4. Determined Story Arc Type

Riches to Rags

instruction: Analyze the story and classify it into one of the following story arc types based on the protagonist's condition at each major event. Explain your reasoning step by step.
input:
Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) Jane Doe, an immensely dedicated critical care nurse, single-handedly juggles waking up before dawn for her long hours at work and raising her bright-eyed eleven-year-old daughter.
2) Secretly, she wrestles with an unseen adversary — her chronic and debilitating heart disease that leaves her weak and gasping on her bad days.
3) Known primarily for her grit and resilience at work, Jane conceals her struggle from her colleagues.
4) Every day, she expertly navigates to the quiet shadows of the hospital, seeking solace within the confines of the sterile restrooms where she adheres strictly to her heart medication regime.
5) Jane spends her life on the razor's edge, precariously attempting to shield her vital career from her personal health challenges.
6) One day, her internal world of fragile equilibrium spirals into uncertainty when she stumbles upon a hushed conversation between two hospital administrators.
7) As the furtive conversation resonates through her mind, Jane becomes progressively encumbered by an unshakeable terror.
8) During an unplanned rendezvous in the hospital cafeteria, Jane finds herself trapped in an uneasy discussion with the chief nurse.
9) A relentless wave of unease inundates her.
10) During a particularly demanding day, Jane goes about her daily routine and suffers a sudden on-set cardiac crisis, a vivid manifestation of her desperate battle against her heart disease.
11) In the middle of medical act and personal struggle, Jane's patient, a recently retired attorney, becomes privy to her concealed infirmity.
12) Over succeeding days, Jane's interaction with the former attorney deepens.
13) The retired attorney offers to use his legal acumen for Jane protection, extending an arm of friendship and professional aid.
14) As Jane becomes more open with the lawyer, her heart episodes increase.
15) As she navigates through the turbulence of her life, Jane acts in dual roles, transcending from a dedicated nurse to an undercover investigator.
16) However, her courage soon proves a steep price.
17) In the midst of her unscheduled research, during her night shift, Jane's heart gives way.
18) Caught in a twist of fate, Jane transitions from an adept caregiver to an emergency care patient within the sterile confines of the city hospital.
19) Throughout her hospitalization, Jane bravely faces her ailment, sharing her deeply personal experiences of managing a chronic disease while working to heal others.
20) As news about her health condition becomes public during her recuperation, a harsh consequence materializes.
21) Devastated and jobless, Jane finds her pride bruised and morale battered.
22) With the aid of the retired attorney, they launch a lawsuit against the city hospital, alleging wrongful termination and blatant health-policy discrimination.
23) Their legal battle draws national media attention.
24) Jane's fight pushes the issue of health discrimination into spotlight, sparking an intense debate about equal rights and hospital policies.
25) The judgment reverberates strongly against the city hospital — they are found guilty of blatant health discrimination.
26) The healthcare sector begins to witness a growing wave of tolerance.
27) However, Jane's health markedly declines.
28) A dreadful cardiac episode leaves her reeling and she collapses onto the cold floor of her modest living room.
29) In a distorting echo of the past, Jane is once again rushed to the city hospital.
30) While Jane wrestles with death, news of the healthcare policy amendment post her verdict spreads nationwide.
31) Even as death mercilessly descends on Jane, outside her sterile hospital room, a triumph is celebrated.
32) Jane's struggle is immortalized with the unveiling of a granite memorial plaque in the hospital's atrium.
33) The hospital authorities commemorate Jane Doe by celebrating her relentless fight against health discrimination.
34) Prominent among those attending the emotional ceremony are Jane's teary-eyed daughter and the retired attorney, both poignant reminders of Jane's enduring legacy.
35) Jane's tireless struggle leaves an indelible mark on the healthcare sector.
36) She leaves behind a powerful legacy enriched with the promise of equality and acceptance, ensuring her spirit continues to resonate, undying and eternal.

- Riches to Rags: Protagonist starts high and ends lower (e.g., 10→9→8→6→0)
- Man in a Hole: Protagonist falls into trouble but recovers (e.g., 6→2→1→4→10)

- Double Man in a Hole: Two cycles of fall and recovery (e.g., 6→2→7→4→10)

- Oedipus: Start high, fall, recover, final fall (e.g., 10→4→7→9→1)
output:
### TASK 1: Identify the Protagonist and 5 Major Events

The protagonist in the story is Jane Doe, a dedicated critical care nurse.

Here are 5 major events in the story:

1. **Event 1:** Jane's internal world of fragile equilibrium spirals into uncertainty when she stumbles upon a hushed conversation between two hospital administrators. (Sentence 6)
2. **Event 2:** Jane suffers a sudden on-set cardiac crisis, a vivid manifestation of her desperate battle against her heart disease. (Sentence 10)
3. **Event 3:** With the aid of the retired attorney, Jane launches a lawsuit against the city hospital, alleging wrongful termination and blatant health-policy discrimination. (Sentence 22)
4. **Event 4:** The judgment reverberates strongly against the city hospital — they are found guilty of blatant health discrimination. (Sentence 25)
5. **Event 5:** Jane's struggle is immortalized with the unveiling of a granite memorial plaque in the hospital's atrium after her death. (Sentence 32)

### TASK 2: Describe the Protagonist's State and Changes at Each Event

1. **Event 1:** Jane's state is one of uncertainty and fear, which is a decline from her previous state of fragile equilibrium. She was managing her heart disease and balancing her work and personal life, but this event sets her on a downward trajectory.
2. **Event 2:** Jane's state is one of physical and emotional crisis, which is a further decline from her previous state of uncertainty. Her heart disease has taken a turn for the worse, and she is struggling to cope.
3. **Event 3:** Jane's state is one of determination and resilience, which is an improvement from her previous state of crisis. She has found an ally in the retired attorney and is taking action against the hospital, which gives her a sense of purpose and hope.
4. **Event 4:** Jane's state is one of vindication and triumph, which is a further improvement from her previous state of determination. She has won her lawsuit against the hospital, and her struggle has led to a significant change in the healthcare sector.
5. **Event 5:** Jane's state is one of legacy and remembrance, which is a bittersweet conclusion to her story. Although she has passed away, her struggle has left a lasting impact on the healthcare sector, and she is remembered as a champion of equality and acceptance.

### TASK 3: Classify the Story Arc Type

Based on the protagonist's condition throughout the story, I would classify the story arc type as a **Double Man in a Hole**.

The story follows Jane's journey as she falls into a dilemma (her heart disease and the hospital's discriminatory policies) and finds a way out (her lawsuit and the subsequent change in the healthcare sector). However, her journey is not a straightforward one; she faces multiple setbacks and challenges along the way, including her cardiac crisis and her eventual death. Despite these setbacks, Jane's determination and resilience ultimately lead to a positive outcome, and her legacy lives on.

The Double Man in a Hole story arc type is characterized by two cycles of dilemma and recovery, which is evident in Jane's story. She faces an initial dilemma (her heart disease and the hospital's policies), recovers (her lawsuit and the change in the healthcare sector), and then faces another dilemma (her eventual death), but her legacy ultimately recovers and lives on.

### TASK 4: State the Determined Story Arc Type

**Double Man in a Hole**

input:
Story, broken down into numbered sentences:
1) Alex is a jovial and quick-witted man from Mentone, a humble Georgian village.
2) Employed at the village's only car wash establishment, he converts any ordinary day into an amusing one with his side-splitting observations and contagiously funny comments about the mundaneness of rural life.
3) This fun-loving individual was no less than a local celebrity - his lively humor and hidden intellection blending eloquently to leave an amusing impression on the community.
4) The serene existence disrupted one day when a poised city girl named Sophia, with a vibrant city aura, drove into Mentone, her shiny ruby-red Ferrari glimmering under the sun.
5) Her sudden arrival stirred a wave of surprise and curiosity among the otherwise peaceful village dwellers.
6) Sophia's cosmopolitan sophistication was a stark contrast to the laid-back ambiance and amicable spirit of the modest village, creating a sense of excitement among the residents.
7) Catching a glance of Sophia's dust-covered luxury car, Alex is left longing for an opportunity to bring back its original shine.
8) He welcomes this break from the usual farm trucks and beaten-up buses he typically deals with.
9) The first meeting between the two at the car wash made for a hilarious affair.
10) Their wondering eyes and contrasting worldviews of each other's lifestyles set the stage for tons of laughs.
11) Sophia left her precious vehicle under Alex's care while she decided to explore the countryside.
12) She handed him a detailed manual carrying meticulous instructions about how she wished her car to be handled and cleaned.
13) As soon as Sophia left the scene, Alex’s pals doubled over in laughter as they jokingly visualized the regimented city life of Sophia.
14) Disregarding Sophia’s meticulous guidelines, Alex, feeling mischievous, decided to use her Ferrari for rip-roaring rides around the countryside, accompanied by his equally audacious friends.
15) One of the most unforgettable exploits was when they decided to participate in the local county fair's hilarious tractor race, barreling down dirt tracks amid tractors and worn-out pickup trucks in a flashy Ferrari.
16) Despite the fun, Alex experiences a pang of guilt when he notices minor dents and scratches on the vehicle during their adventurous expeditions.
17) Things get even trickier when the village gets wind of Sophia's imminent return.
18) A wave of panicked hilarity swept over the peaceful town, residents imagining her reaction upon finding her fancy car in a less than pristine state.
19) Meanwhile, Sophia was quickly falling in love with the warm and welcoming nature of the country folk, a deeply contrasting experience she relished, compared to her usual detached city life.
20) The unhurried pace of Mentone life, along with its intimate festivals, became a source of joy for her.
21) Moreover, Alex's boundless, hearty laughter made her experience infinitely delightful, making her crave his amiable companionship more and more.
22) As time passed, a distinct romance began to simmer between Alex and Sophia.
23) Their love story was infused with humor at every turn, such as the time when Alex attempted a romantic candlelit dinner that quickly escalated into a wild food fight.
24) As Sophia’s return neared, Alex found his guilt and anxiety piling up over the thought of confessing the damage his merry rides had inflicted on Sophia’s cherished Ferrari.
25) In an attempt to cover up his blunder, Alex launched into a series of hilarious actions aiming at repairing the car himself, despite his very limited knowledge of automobile mechanics.
26) On the verge of despair, Alex decided to involve his fellow villagers, who had become invested in his predicament, to secretly assist him in the herculean task of fixing the luxury vehicle.
27) The whole village came together in a heartwarming display of solidarity, mimicking a clumsy, amateur yet determined pit crew.
28) Upon her return, Sophia was greeted with her renovated car.
29) The transformation left her in pure shock and disbelief.
30) Initially, she felt a swell of disappointment for her once pristine, untouched sports car was now irrevocably modified.
31) However, anger gave way to understanding as she laid eyes on her unique, handcrafted Ferrari.
32) The earnest attempts made by Alex in tandem with his heartfelt apology gradually lightened her mood.
33) Sophia found herself increasingly drawn towards the serene tranquility of Mentone and the joy that Alex's infectious laughter brought into her life.
34) In an uplifting turn of events, Sophia decided to shed her city life for good and become a permanent resident of Mentone, embracing the simple pleasures of rural life.
35) A hilarious montage followed her decision, depicting Sophia acclimating to farming chores, partaking in village fairs, and living a wholesome and fulfilling life alongside Alex.
36) Sophia's revamped Ferrari remains a constant, tangible reminder of the life-altering detour she had the good fortune of experiencing.
37) The endearing journey of Sophia and Alex unfolds, their lives filled with comic misadventures and instances of genuine joy amidst life's simplicity.
38) The film wraps up with a memorable scene where Sophia, Alex, and the entire village share a hearty laugh together.

Story Arc Types:
- Rags to Riches: Protagonist starts disadvantaged and ends better (e.g., 0→1→2→4→10)
- Riches to Rags: Protagonist starts high and ends lower (e.g., 10→9→8→6→0)
- Man in a Hole: Protagonist falls into trouble but recovers (e.g., 6→2→1→4→10)
- Icarus: Protagonist rises then falls dramatically (e.g., 2→4→9→5→1)
- Double Man in a Hole: Two cycles of fall and recovery (e.g., 6→2→7→4→10)
- Cinderella: Rise, setback, ultimate triumph (e.g., 1→7→4→1→10)
- Oedipus: Start high, fall, recover, final fall (e.g., 10→4→7→9→1)
output:

The protagonist of the story is Alex, a jovial and quick-witted man from Mentone.

The 5 major events in the story are:

1. Sophia's arrival in Mentone and Alex's first encounter with her (sentences 4-10)
2. Alex's decision to disregard Sophia's instructions and use her Ferrari for rip-roaring rides (sentences 14-16)

4. Sophia's reaction to the renovated Ferrari and Alex's apology (sentences 29-32)
5. Sophia's decision to shed her city life and become a permanent resident of Mentone (sentences 34-38)

**Task 2: Describe the protagonist's state and how it changed relative to the previous events**

1. At the first event, Alex is in a state of excitement and curiosity, having just met Sophia and being introduced to her city aura. His condition is neutral, as he is simply reacting to a new situation.

2. At the second event, Alex's state changes to one of mischief and playfulness, as he decides to disregard Sophia's instructions and use her Ferrari for fun. His condition improves, as he is enjoying himself and feeling carefree.

3. At the third event, Alex's state changes to one of guilt and anxiety, as he realizes the damage he has caused to Sophia's Ferrari and panics about her imminent return. His condition worsens, as he is now facing the consequences of his actions.

4. At the fourth event, Alex's state changes to one of relief and hope, as Sophia reacts to the renovated Ferrari and accepts his apology. His condition improves, as he is able to make amends and potentially salvage his relationship with Sophia.

5. At the fifth event, Alex's state changes to one of happiness and fulfillment, as Sophia decides to shed her city life and become a permanent resident of Mentone. His condition improves further, as he is now in a loving relationship and surrounded by the people and way of life he loves.

**Task 3: Classify the story arc type based on the protagonist's condition throughout**

Based on the changes in Alex's condition throughout the story, I would classify the story arc type as "Man in a Hole." Alex starts in a neutral state, then rises to a peak of mischief and playfulness, before falling into a hole of guilt and anxiety. However, he is able to climb out of this hole and ultimately ends up in a better state than at the beginning, having found love and happiness with Sophia.

The story arc type is confirmed by the fact that Alex's condition improves from the first turning point (meeting Sophia) to the last turning point (Sophia's decision to stay in Mentone). The story follows a clear trajectory of rise, fall, and recovery, which is characteristic of the "Man in a Hole" story arc type.

**Task 4: State the determined story arc type**

Man in a Hole
